Are but too apt to give the least of favours
That a Prince Vouchsafes a Lady.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: You are wise
And noble: and give me your fair leave
To ask a question, my intelligence
Assur'd me most undoubted.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: If it be truth
My Soul dares not deny it.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Then thus most noble Lady;
Did not the King once love you?

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: I did not think
Heaven had reveal'd what I had thought a secret—
To his heart and mine— suppose he did, and yet
I blush to charge him with a guilty truth.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: It was my apprehension—

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: And since 'tis made your knowledge, I must further say
My wrongs are fit to be convey'd as far
As the world has bounds, or fame can stretch
Her wings to bear e'm.

sp.speaker: Bàss.
sp.l: I fear too sadly—
But should you own this claim to his affection now.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: My love's a truth too dear to smother, nor
Did I come, but arm'd with resolutions
Worthy of my Soul. And 'tis my highest service
To his Queen (whose vertues I much honour)
If I reveal to her my claim, and thence
Mark out her dangers in this man of falshood
She enjoys.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I know you would not charge
Him with this crime, on purpose to create
Repentance; or if you did, who knows
What were your dangers (I speak it not to
Fright you Madam) that here must look like some
Prodigious Star on a great King, made now
So fully happy in the bed and glories of a Queen—
Which how he will resent—

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: Let it be death, 'tis welcom from him.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Heaven avert it, Madam; yet 'tis not safe
To tempt a passion past recall, though I
Want not a pity to your vertue.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: I thank your goodness.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Or say you could attract his past affection
; And in each beam of yours, more deeply wound
His heart then ever (as you have all things
Summ'd at Natures dearest cost, that can
Inrich a Beauty) were it not glory
To recede from such a Conquest.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: Your Counsel's noble I confess.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Besides we have a custom here that does
Impower each common man to loose the very
Gordian knot of love in marriage,
That other Countries hold inviolate:
What may then a King do to enjoy
So bright a Mistress as your self?

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: I find the World in this degenerate
Faithless age of man has yet one
Worthy left:
Know then, most noble Prince, your Counsel does
Conspire with the honour of Statyra's heart;
And though I had a more superiour title
To the Kings affection then the Queen can claim
Though made his Consort; yet I for her sake now
Forgive his breach of Faith; nay more, if 'twere
Requir'd, would freely give my life, to see
Their Loves most happy.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Give me the honour
Of your hand, to pay my humble adoration
Of this vertue.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: My stay shall not be longer here
Then taking leave, becomes me of the King.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: 'Twill speak your worth.
The King— your pardon Madam—

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Statyra! how dost thou like thy welcom
In our Court?

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: As more then I intended to receive.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Thou can'st not soon be weary
Of these shades, and pleasant walks, where
Nightingales will meet, and sing
New ravishments to entertain thy beauties:
More glad to welcom thy appearance, then
The morning joys, or evenings splendor that
Invites their rest. I think thou might'st be well
Content to live here still.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: My honour is no child
To be deluded with such toys, though gay
As Paradise when first it's sweetness bloom'd,
While but a thought of crime does ripen near me.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Thou shal't be here as innocent as flowers
That yield their smiles unto the distant Sun.
You'l grant me sure, so much, Statyra?

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: I'le rather welcom death then yield to stay
A minute longer near your person.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: I know thou art not so unkind.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: Alas I came without design of love,
Though once your lover.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Statyra! hold, go not
Too far in goodness, lest Heaven (to surprise
My wonder) take thee hence, and place thee there
A Star, or make me fall I know not whither.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: I have done Sir— nor shall my presence give you
More concern; or further accent repetition
Of your sin to Heaven and me; that in despight
Of all the darts of Love (so late my wound)
Can with this smiling ease and calm of soul
Bid you farewel for ever.—
sp.stage: [She offers to go, the King stays her.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: You must not,
Shall not leave me thus—

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: You will not, Sir, detain me
Here by force?— what will your Court then whisper,
Or the bolder world convey to both our infamies?
I hope I have made enough expression
Of my affection—

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: 'Tis but to give thee more assurance
Of my love, for which I dare adventure
Life and Crown.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: That word! oh my heart!—

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: Then know who 'tis you stay—
And thus dare frown upon your will.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: And what I thought this breast should have conceal'd,
I'le utter with a boldness does become my honour—
And when you know it, you'l perhaps, as soon
Cherish a Tygress near your bosom—
Know Sir— I came with full intent to kill you—
Mark me well: to kill you— for your faithless promise;
But that the vertues of your Queen with-held me,
In whom I wish you ever bless'd: the whiteness
Of whose Soul, I thought it sin to cloud
(From act of mine) with sorrow.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Forgive me Heaven;
This Woman is some Angel sure; I can
No longer hold but pay my reverence.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: We are interrupted— my Guard there!—
Convey that Lady from my sight, and see
Her safe consin'd within her lodgings.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Let me beg for her freedom, though I do it
On my knees—

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: I must not grant it; she came
To ruine my content, perhaps in thee;
A Treason too she has confest against my life.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: Let me deserve your fair opinion, Madam,
Though I dye.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Away with her— how does my Parisatis?—
sp.stage: [Ex. Statyra with the Captain of the Guard.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Never better— this dissipates my fear.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Embassadresses from
The Queen Mandana are arriv'd.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: See their reception want no state our Court
Can give; they shall have Audience speedily.
Some thoughts require me to my Closet first.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Bassanes, never so happy, as this minute
In which I prov'd the fix'd assurance of
My Kings affection. The Persian beauty
Who but so late gave apprehensions to
My love, is now no more my fear.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: She is a noble Lady,
And gave me confirmation of her honour.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: 'Tis most unquestion'd.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: She does intend suddenly
To return back to Persia.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Alas! the King
(To my great grief) in much displeasure
Has restrain'd her.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I hope she'l soon have liberty.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: It shall not want my intercession.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Pray Heav'n this be no Artifice.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: True love is soon confirm'd; but in that Brest
Suspicion storms, it ne're can anchor'd rest.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Our Petition had but small success.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: No matter, as to thy case; did not I
Promise to serve thee?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: But where's the faith
Believes it possible?

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: If it be next a Miracle,
And do the feat, thou'lt welcom the effect?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: However, my obligement's great to your endeavours.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: What if a smile or look of thine, or a toy
As inconsiderate as the least lock of thy hair,
Produce his Loves return, as I apply it;
Hast thou not reason to thank the means?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis granted.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Therefore believe well; rememb'ring that
We are told, a dram of faith can do
Far greater wonders.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You shall confirm me,
But I hope it is no Charm or Magick?
I am strangely fearful of the Devil.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Rather a means from Heaven! my Mother
Left it as a Legacy to me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: A Recipe most Wives may wish for here.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: I thought to have given it to the Queen,
But that perhaps 'twere death to own,
And this our custom unrevok'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I hope her vertues ne're will want affection.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: As it effects, I'le tell thee more.
Here comes thy Husband, and I am prepar'd
For him to purpose— thou must withdraw
Till I give thee notice to appear.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Madam! your most humble servant.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: And I perhaps ten times more yours.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: This sounds briskly.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Not that I intend to instance,
You have parted with a deserving Lady,
And so press a reconciliation from
The doctrine and uses of Love, as some Matrons
Amongst us might perhaps ring in your ears
In the like case.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Far be it from me to
Think it, Madam; I know you are well bred,
And must therefore understand what better
Belongs to our Mode, and a Gentleman, then so.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Well said Gallant— but I hope you'l not teach
My Husband to follow your example;
And like such a Buck as your self, break
Through the toyl and bonds of Marriage;
Though some of you allow it no more, then
A State device to catch fools.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: This is a Witty Rogue; a Wife that understand;
The intrigues of a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Then say, my husbands wife
Should think you a fine Gentleman—

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: I understand you Madam.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: And were willing to bestow some affection
On your worth.—

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Go on Lady, go on; you are
Coming to a point indeed.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: There it is, you have it to a hair—
sp.stage: [Gives him a Bracelet inclos'd in a Paper.
sp.l: I hope you will keep Counsel—

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: O Madam! 'twere sin to doubt it.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: And wear it carefully, for the owners sake
I mean, and so farewel kind Foscaris;
If this fail, thou'rt proof above Mortal.
Now to be near and act further as occasion serves.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: What have I here? I'le open it carefully,
And first taste it by the smell; it scents
Most Lady-like, and amorous; methinks
It moves too, I know not how: Oh these Women
Are rare contrivers in these Scenes of Love—
Now for the enclos'd—
Ha, ha, ha, a Bracelet of a lock of Hair,
In colour much resembling my Wives: but
Such a trick on me, were to little purpose,
I'le tangle no more there— but now I think on't,
I have found the knack; as sure as I am made
Of flesh and blood, 'tis Melvissa courts me
For her self, for which purpose she handles
Andrages, her husband, at that rate.
'Tis a witty-gay female, as most within
Our Kingdom; and it seems the Rascal's
Willing to graft his fore-head, and be beholding
To his Friend for the Horn. In the mean time
I'le pleasure her desire, and wear her favour.
The Devil on't, it warms the vein that leads
To the Heart strangely; and 'tis love I feel
In abundance— I must vent it somewhere,
Or I shall burn to ashes; 'tis most certain I am
Charm'd to purpose, and 'tis odds but some evil spirit
Waits at my elbow.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: None but thy better Genius—

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Ha! a voice too, then there is a Devil in the
Case 'tis manifest— what art thou, and from whence?

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: I am a Spirit belonging to the element of fire.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Thou hast some possession of me already then,
Who am flame all over— what is thy business?

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Love, kindest Love.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: The same is mine, and
Since thou art a kind Familiar, I dare ask
Thee a question— Art thou a Genius of Love at large
According to our Gallantizing Mode? or art thou for
A more peculiar Courtship?

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: I incite Honourable, and Matrimonial Love.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: A most Heroick Devil indeed;
But take a care how thou dost otherwise appear to me,
Lest my sword make bold with one of thy limbs,
And it prove afterwards to belong to some
Sorcerer, or Witch.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: You need not fear that.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Prethee avoid me then, I would not willingly be haunted
By a Matrimonial Genius of all other.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Your desire is granted—
While only I'le thy heart incite
To love thy fair deserted Wife,
For whose sake, I am oblig'd thy sense to ply,
Since on thy wrist thou didst a philter tye.
And so farewel.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Adieu, adieu! had ever man such a Dialogue
As this?

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Be confident I have perform'd to purpose.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Nay more to his greater
Terror, I withdrew here, and counterfeited my self
A Spirit.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Most excellent!

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: And had
Such pleasant discourse with him.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You have done above my expectation.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: He comes on fiercely I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: And yet I do not find my hair stares, or
A cold sweat on me, enough to dissolve me to a gelly,
Like some stories I have heard of this kind.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: See, he's here, observe a little— in the mean time
I'le withdraw.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Whilst I feel such a heat dispers'd through every vein
Of my body, no man, or longing virgin ever felt
The like in any burning wish, or actual enjoyment—
Well Foscaris, thou hast got a tickling spirit in thee.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I perceive it takes.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: And yet methinks
It should not be in the power of Magick to make
Me affect my cast-off Wife; if it prove otherwise,
What a confounded Lover am I then— she's here.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Now I'le approach him.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: As I am a man, 'tis she I long for,
The very element of fire is met
Within me, and my heart rises to my very lips
At her appearance.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The Physick works; now to handle this patient.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Oh thou art bright indeed Clarina;
Ariadnes Crown of Stars is Copper
To thy Eyes, and in each look methinks thou
Stain'st the evenings glory.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Good kind Sir, keep off, 'tis towards bed-time.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: 'Tis thither I would go with thee Love, and twine
More happily then ever! Alas, I did but this
To love thee ten times better then before;
As men restrain themselves from food they like
To make the next meal better.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Keep your ground good Sir Amorous;
You and I must not come to the close embrace
So easily; and lest you should be boyst'rous,
I'le be gone.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Stay but a twilights time longer—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis more then I can well afford you.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Nay prethee let me beg it though I kneel.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You deserve some penance; I'le not intreat you
To be sparing.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Foscaris kneeling! and to his own Wife?
The world sure turns round, or Plato's year
Is come about; if this Diamond he late
Discarded should again be Trump?—
What Foscaris! pensive?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Oh I am undone!

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Nay, thou'lt laugh me into shame enough
When thou know'st it.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: By no means.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Why, I am wounded by Cupid the wrong way?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: I scarce know how to tell thee.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Nay prethee let me know.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Understand then I am in love
With my own cast petticoat; if that be not
A curse to a Scythian Husband, I'le
Challenge fate to do worse if possible.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Though I found thee on thy knees, I hope
Thou dost not pray over love again to thy Wife.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: But I do, and at such an intolerable rate,
That were every sense of mine a several soul,
She might command 'em all to express it.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Is't possible?—

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: And more, look well to thy self,
I fear thy Wife's an Inchantress.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: If thou dost not see her flying steeple high,
And thy self atop on her shortly, I'le hang
As high for't.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: But you thought there was no such thing
As Charm or Magick in Love, and that our
Scythian Wives would have still continued such
Tame things, as like bob'd Eyesses, they might
Have been turn'd off; and took to hand at pleasure.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: I have prov'd the Experiment dearly:
Take care and mock not, lest thou art beheld
Converted to a Cat, and cry Mew
To keep her company.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Is this the man
That could defie Cupid and all his Arts?
Nay shoot your Darts contrary to his, at
A minutes warning— was it not so?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: I thought I could, till more then mortal powers
Conspir'd against me.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: And for a Wife, 'twas
Such a potion, must have no more to do
With your palate.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: The very name of her
Inflames me like fire.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: A little more to cool you
And I have done; come I'le put you in mind,
Of a Julip of your own composition;

l.hi: What though her Eyes are black,

sp.l: And kisses with a knack, &c.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: No more, no more, though I deserve to be
Bitten with a Satyr could sting worse then
Scorpions.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Well; I have done.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Let's shake hands then,
And go thus postur'd to the Frantick Society here,
Amongst which I'le dye,
If e're there were two such Fanatick presidents
Of Husbands as our selves: Oh 'twould make such a
Novelty of distempers!

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: And there endure a little of the twig,
Shall we?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: By any means;
Thou for observing thy Wife with such a
Fond affection, as I beyond dotage
Long for mine again.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Good Foscaris,
Enough of this extravagancy: In the mean time
I have so far the better of the malady,
That I have no fear of thy relapse,
And for a cure, let me advise one more gentle;
Let's drink some Wine, and give it spirit
In Clarina's health.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Oh that I could taste her lips once more—
And mark me friend, 'tis odds as I am a Gentleman,
But in spight of all prevention I shall
Hang or drown my self for love, e're the next Moon.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Come I'le take care of thee.
sp.stage: Enter Tysamnes, Parisatis, Bassanes, Clarina, Melvissa, Toxaris, Alvanes, and Araxis, &c.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: We understand Bassanes, that the Embassadresses
From the Queen Mandana are arriv'd.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: They are, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Attend them to our presence.
An Embassy few Courts have seen before,
Where Women bear their Princes Errands,
And rule supreamly even our Sex.
What think you Ladies, were your case alike
With us?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: For mine I should not wish it, Sir,
'Twere too injurious to the right of men.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: You are a little of the kindest Lady—
For my part, Sir, were I born under the like
Favourable Aspect of Venus, 'tis odds but I
Should wear a Bow and Quiver, to maintain
The priviledge— you'l pardon, Sir, my freedom.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: A witty sprightly Lady— and yet I dare believe
There's none of all you Gentlemen, that has
A Wife predominant, who does not own
Submission to the custom here.—

sp.speaker: Tax.
sp.l: This touches home.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: I am confirm'd, that were the case my consorts here,
(So dear unto my soul) she would not claim
Her self exempted.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: That parenthesis was odly plac'd.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You know I am all obedience, Sir,
And hope you'l now receive such offers, from
This our neighbour-Queen, as will not give your thoughts
The least disturbance; nor would I have a War
Wherein my Sex should fight, were I made a party
In the cause, or injury.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Thou art all Excellence.
sp.stage: Enter Bassanes with Renone, and Cydane the Embassadresses.
sp.l: Now Ladies, your Queens pleasure.

sp.speaker: Renone.
sp.l: Who does by us, most Royal Sir, congratulate
Your great accession to this Throne, and more, your joys
In this your fair and vertuous Queen, who scarce
Has equal in her Sex: to which (if possible)
Her wishes do yet adde more happiness.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: This is but usual form of State: proceed.

sp.speaker: Cyd.
sp.l: 'Tis what our Queen expects you'l welcom,
Who waves dispute of Territories,
The usual great concerns of Thrones;
And has but one demand instead of all,
To make your Greatness: whence may spring
A lasting league betwixt her mighty Crown
And yours.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Speak it then!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I hope 'twill find reception.

sp.speaker: Cyd.
sp.l: Then know, our Mighty Mistress does demand
By us an Abrogation of that most
Rigid usage here, from which the Husbands will
Is too much Lord of love.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Sure, you mistake your Embassy?

sp.speaker: Ren.
sp.l: Nor can she reign without a blush must stain
Her glories, should she not (if deny'd)
Compel by arms her Sexes fair relief.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Nobly urg'd.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Methinks I could fight in this Cause my self.

sp.speaker: Arax.
sp.l: The King is mov'd.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Observe the Queen.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Your Queen's too bold with us in this demand;
But she's a Woman.

sp.speaker: Cyd.
sp.l: And soon you'l find, she'l slight
All dangers in this Cause: nor is the world
Unknowing, that her arms (though guided
By the conduct of our Sex) has oft gave
Wars rough Laws to men.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Let me then intercede, my Royal Husband,
I would not have a quarrel in this Cause,
(Although I doubt not from your love security)
The world I know would say you but defend
A most unkind prerogative; and since 'tis thus,
Bestow it as a bounty on the Sex for my sake.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Can this proceed from Parisatis?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: As truly as I wish your peace and love.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Thou dost mistake in both—

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Besides, what honour wer't in such a Cause
To be a Conquerour? or on your Warlike Trophee to
Inscribe, you did subdue the force of Women,
Led by a neighbour Queen, whose bravery
Of soul, deserves esteem and wonder—
I know you'l condescend.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Away, thou dost abuse thy Love and me.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Or else endeavour'st by compliance with
This Embassy, to betray the honour of
This Crown, and People; take which you like—
And know thou hast forfeited thy Being
In my soul.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Heaven defend.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: And tell your Queen I'le reign
A King of men in spight of all her power
Of Spinsters: whose honour by this grant would be
The mock of Women. Nor do I doubt their hearts
And swords will join with mine to assert this
Nations right.

sp.speaker: Tox.
sp.l: The King is much incens'd.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: I hope 'twill not reflect upon the Queen.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: And by my Act, to assure the world how much
I'le own my Subjects priviledge, behold my Queen.

sp.speaker: Cyd.
sp.l: A Lady full of Grace and Vertue—

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Oh my fears!

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Who with no more concern I'le cast away,
Then Indians do a Pearl, that ne're did know
It's value; and from this hour no more my Wife.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Must it be so?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Consider Sir, this Act
May prove a rash one—

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: My resolution's fixt— nor do I fear
What Law can act, though hence I reign not jointly
With this Queen, while by the power I possess,
I can create a right above it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Nor shall I plead a word
Against your Will, though it severely fall
Upon my Love; or mention what should be
Your gratitude to me, that gave you both
My self and Crown, and yet will give my life,
If your concern require it—
You'l give me time convenient to withdraw.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Thou shalt to any place retire within
My Crowns Dominion, where thou shalt live
In state and greatness of a Queen—
And so farewel.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Adieu, my dearest.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: This action of the King was unexpected.

sp.speaker: Arax.
sp.l: Such as must breed some strange distemper here.

sp.speaker: Tox.
sp.l: I wish our Almanacks were all burnt else.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: To morrow you shall have our Letters to your Queen.

sp.speaker: Renone.
sp.l: And as becomes her she'l resent this Act.

sp.speaker: Tysaem.
sp.l: Bassanes—

sp.speaker: Cydan.
sp.l: Madam, you have our pity.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The Queen deserves a sorrow
From all Hearts.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: She has deeply mine.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Though life has many ways to lose it's comforts,
Few hinder the distressed means of death:
And let my sad example teach my Sex,
That when they love embarque with men, 'tis like
A vessel, that with guilded streamers sails
On dangerous Seas, and in each calm must think
This smooth-fac'd Ocean may their Barques soon sink.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Parisatis in a Mourning Vail led by Bassanes.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I Want no sense of your afflictions, Madam.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: 'Tis like your worth.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: And dare express it more
Then entertaining of your griefs by naked Accents,
That were too low and common for Bassanes heart;
Each vulgar ear that hears from rumours breath,
Will do as much, and glory in the hope
Of making stubborn Heaven bend to hear
Your sufferings.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You are a Prince ally'd unto my Crown,
Nor can I doubt, but every vein of yours
Ha's many streams of honour—

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Know, Madam,
Since you are pleas'd to call me worthy of
Your great Alliance; I want no heart to tell
The King, your Husband (though sitting on the Throne)
His ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I wish I had been truly charg'd with any crime
That might have given his Act in my desertion,
Some vizard to out-face the world: I dare believe
The Law that first here gave this liberty to man,
Did tacitely imply the Husband should
Not be a lawless Tyrant to the Wife.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: The injustice is too palpable; and
Fitter 'twere this Law had no more being,
Or the Sex of women against Natures
Made supreme, then thus to be imbitter'd
'Gainst your vertue,
Though smooth'd and guilded over with pretexts,
He calls State Policy, and Marriage Interest,
But simply Artifice to bring another
To his Throne and Bed.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I fear 'tis too much a truth.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Statyra is no doubt design'd to shine
In this Meridian, by your fair remove:
But think not, Madam, that your Eclipse of
Glory can pass without your Subjects due
Remorse, and vindication: he is a King here
But as you made him so, in giving him
Your self a Queen; and from your love has only
Title to your Subjects hearts.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And had the world
Been mine in Kingdoms, with as many Hearts,
My affection had dispos'd 'em all to him.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: You have given proof above parallel.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: But this ingratitude does combate with my soul!

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Permit, I serve your Royal Vertue.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I know thou dar'st revenge my wrong, and hast
An interest in thy blood and merits, that
Can guide this Nations Arms, and raise a stream
Of vulgar force, enough to sink Tysamnes
Even to the depth of ruine, though fortify'd with
All the power he now enjoys.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I will imploy my utmost in your service.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I have I see a Subject great, brave, and faithful;
In spight of all adversity— Bassanes
Thou wilt obey me strictly?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Be danger what it will;
Nor need you question, but the arm I shall apply
Is strong enough to right, or else revenge
Your injuries: nor want I means prepar'd
Even at this minute, that shall soon perform
The least breath of your commands.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Then know, I do enjoin you all obedience
To the King—

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: How, Madam?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I mean Tysamnes,
Who has thrown me from his heart, and that far
More strict, if possible, then had he met
My Love with equal constancy— I would
Not live and underact the part of virtue.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: You oblige me now to be your enemy—
Who knows how soon you may be taken from
The world by him, that thus has cast you from
His bosom?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: 'Tis not inglorious if I die,
Or split on any rock,
This storm shall throw me on,
If Innocence be my harbour.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: The Worm that's trod on, bows in some displeasure
When it's griev'd; what should then do your Greatness?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: But vertue's yet more gentle, whose value's
Most refin'd by suffering— I know
You will obey me.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Since 'tis your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And be sure give out 'twas Act of State,
Or Crime in me, or any thing thou can'st devise
Most plausible, to assure the people
To Tysamnes. And more, that 'tis my strict

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: The Queen, Sir, is withdrawn.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Drax.
sp.l: Remov'd Sir, none knows whither.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: I fear she has taken some precipitate resolve.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: The joys this news will bring,
Must soon cause her appearance,
Where e're she is retir'd.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Make strict and speedy search,
He wants no wealth brings happy tidings first.

sp.speaker: Eum. Drax.
sp.l: We'll use all diligence.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Bring forth Statyra.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I'le wait her to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: 'Tis fit she know
How much I have offended for her sake.
Statyra, I must beg a pardon of thy vertue.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: Sir, you have prov'd I can forgive.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Thy goodness I have injur'd next my Queens,
And I am making of my peace with Heaven
And her.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: 'Tis worthy of your Soul— But you'l consider, Sir—

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: I do, that 'twas my sin of love to thee
Which did induce this Act, to whom I first
Dispos'd my heart: and would to Heaven I had
Two souls, that I might give one to thy vertue,
And make thee twin in my affection with my Queen;
Excepting whom, the world and womankind
Are but trifles to my heart.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: Mine is as truly yours;
And let this blush excuse my boldness,
If I claim you now my own.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: How's this Statyra?

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: You are made free by Law,
(If such a one this Country owns) and can
That less then plead for my enjoyment now,
So much your Lover?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I did not look for this.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Tempt me not fair Statyra, lest I fall
Below the sin of the Apostate Angels;
And call thy love my second crime.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: I did but mention mine to prove your constancy.
May you for ever live most happy in
Your Queen; and for your sake I'le beg of Heaven
That she may late be taken thither.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Thou art a pattern of perfection—

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: And since you now have made me free, I'le crave
Your leave to respite my return, till I
Congratulate your happy meeting with
Your Queen, and so to Persia, where I'le
Spread your joys.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: This centers with my wish.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Each syllable of thine does give my soul new wonder.
Since not alone, thou can'st my Crime forgive,
But yield I may anothers Lover live.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: You are pleas'd to like my entertainment
Gentlemen; and I am apt enough to be
Proud of your good opinion.

sp.speaker: 1 Court.
sp.l: You are all diversion, Madam, our Court
Has not such another Lady.

sp.speaker: 2 Court.
sp.l: I hope you'l
Give me leave to spend some hours with your converse.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: You may be welcom as I please
Jointly, and severally.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: We understand you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: But methinks you are a little dull (though
Courtly bred) since you speak praises of my Wit,
But have little to say for my Beauty.

sp.speaker: 1 Court.
sp.l: Oh Madam! that's granted, the Court has no such
Star, bating the Queen.

sp.speaker: 2 Court.
sp.l: Besides, your Ladyship
Cannot so far mistake our inclinations,
As to suppose we pay adorations
To the ugly, though ne're so witty;
They are only fit to eat with, provided
They keep good Tables.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Now I perceive you.

sp.speaker: 1 Court.
sp.l: But for you, Madam, (so perfectly taking)
The day is too short to admire you, and
The night to enjoy you.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: You aim well, and 'tis odds
But I guess the mark you'd hit— pray sit a while;
I can afford you some minutes—

sp.speaker: 2 Court.
sp.l: There's no time
Long enough, we are not in haste.—

sp.speaker: 1 Court.
sp.l: 'Tis fit we wait your leisure.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: I keep my lodgings free enough for entertainment,
And live without the fear of Prying Watchers, or the
Jealous Husbands eye.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Oh my torment! she dares me to be jealous too.

sp.speaker: 2 Court.
sp.l: I suppose, Madam, you allow the Gentleman
His times of hawking and hunting, in order
To your more private Recreations.

sp.speaker: 1 Court.
sp.l: Let me be so happy I beseech you,
As to have notice when he is absent.

sp.speaker: 2 Court.
sp.l: Or I, Madam, I should endeavour to serve you.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: I'le try whether I have so much courage
Left, as to mark these things (made up of perfumes
And Perriwigs) in the fore-head with a
Jealous token of mine, e're I am convicted
I wear a horn there my self— now Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: 1 Court.
sp.l: Your Husband, Madam— we are in haste—

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: You need not make so much.

sp.speaker: 2 Court.
sp.l: Your Humble Servant, Sir.—

sp.speaker: 1 Court.
sp.l: The King expects me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: You shall not part with any apprehension
Hence— how now Sir Hot Spur? I must curb you
I faith, if you offer to take such
Careers as these.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: You may command me, Madam— a Lark is not
So dar'd as I am by this Hobby of mine.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Put up your Tool, and remove; your appearance
Was more unseasonable then I look'd for.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Each word she speaks is a Charm; I have not
So much valour in me as to oppose her tongue,
What e're I have done, or dare do otherwise.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: You may now withdraw,
Gentlemen, the King expects you.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Your Servant Lady.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: There is no need of the expression;
I did but act a little of the most to show my prerogative;
I hope you'l say there's one Woman amongst us
Has wit enough to rule her Husband
In spight of Law.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: We'll witness it to wonder, Madam.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Oh Madam! your experiment has done
Wonders; my Husband—

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Loves thee now to purpose.—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Beyond expression.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: My mother prov'd
Such a like Artifice on my father,
For securities sake, yet lov'd him dearly.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You have given good proof in your own,
And for mine, I believe he feels love
In every fiber of his heart; kneels to
Adore me, compares me to Stars, and
Vows that I am more fair then ever.

Oh what a kissing time shall I have on't,
If he and I meet in embrace again?

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Tantalize him well first.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: But to say truth,
I long my self, and would willingly be— you guess—

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: He comes, withdraw a while—

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Oh Madam! you
Have given me a present has had such
Powerful operation on me.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: By this time
You well understand the meaning on't
I assure my self.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: 'Tis love Madam, in extremity.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Did I not tell you so?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: I thought I had hit your sense
To a hair indeed, while I conceiv'd you
As Gentlemen should a Lady in the like case.

sp.speaker: Meiv.
sp.l: It means as good a thing I can assure you.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: But I am doting on my Wife again,
And must (in spight of flesh and blood) woo her
‛ Twice over.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: There 'tis— Alas good Sir, who could
Have thought it in a man of your temper?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: That same bewitching Bracelet you gave me,
Which I am fain to kiss thus reverently
Most minutes of the day, nay, sometimes pray to't;
I can't blame your Husband
For being such a strict Amorist; he
Has had his philter I suppose.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: I never found it needful; if I had,
Perhaps I should have endeavour'd much
To preserve his love.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: There's not a hair
On thy head, but I dare say can do more
Then all the Charms of Medea.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Excuse me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: I should be loth to prove you guilty of
Magick, though 'tis certain.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Proceed, good Sir,
And accuse me, because Heaven has brought
Your affection back again to your Lady;
'Tis odds but I shall answer it.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Well, since 'tis thus,
I forgive thee; and as you are a Woman,
Speak a good word for me.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: That I assure you,
And perhaps have taken more care for you
Then you can imagine— here she comes,
Apply your self first.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: And are we met thus?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: If not happily, you may remove me
With the least breath of yours.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Nay, prethee stay,
I love strangely to look on thee—
O that Eye of thine!—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: And this Cheek, this Lip, (some think not ill)
So often tasted by you, with other amorous
Passages of ours: does this remembrance please you?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: To miracle!—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: And do you truly repent
My desertion, as you protested to me you did?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: From the very bottom of my belly, sweetest.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Had you said your heart, perhaps I had
Took your word, and consented to have met
Your desires on honourable terms.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: This may be a device to bring my passion
To some further mockery: (these she Serpents
Want no wiles) I'le try whether or no
I can dissemble mine, though against the
Power of Magick.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You dare trust my Love?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: I could find in my heart—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You seem'd of late
To adore me so strangely, that I am oblig'd
To take pity of you now for fear of your wits.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: 'Tis certain she mocks me—
I confess I felt a kind flame, or so;
But I did not intend to keep a perpetual
Etna in my bosom, or such a Fevour
Of Love, that will only admit of one Julip.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Melvissa's Arts do fail I fear.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Besides, you Women are such nice things
To handle, and as the world runs now,
Have such superlative devices.—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I can forgive you truly; by this
sp.stage: [Points to his Picture by her side.]

div.l: Image which ne're can hang too near my heart.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: My Picture still there? better and better;
As sure as I live she's charm'd too. Melvissa
I remember told me, that she had done
Something extraordinary for me; I may
Dissemble safely, and if need were, make her
Long as much for me now; what a rare turn
Of Love would that be?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You then continue cruel still?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Alas my pretty fondling, I know thou
Wer't ever kind and tender; but to say truth
I did but counterfeit my passion, a little
To comply with thine, and gave out I had
Receiv'd I know not what charms of Venus,
Supposing thou had'st more wit then to believe
Such wonders.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Alas! what
Could'st thou expect from a man of my complexion?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I'le try my own Art a little then—
Oh my Foscaris!— behold I dye to shew
Thee thy ingratitude

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Help, help, help, my dearest thing of life,
I love thee most outragiously.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Are you in earnest?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Alas! I could even eat thee to express it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: May I confide?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Besides, I'le tell thee more;
I am charm'd to that purpose—
Behold this Bracelet, there's ten thousand
Spirits of Cupid in it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: May I be certain? ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: I'le swear it by a thousand Stars.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: By this good light she jeers me.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: And acts her part unto my wish.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Some other time you and I will dispute terms.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Oh my folly!

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: If you want an Advocate,
Yet command me; in the mean time, I hope
You'l make much of your favour, and so adieu.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: If I am not put in a Ballad, or Lampoon'd
By some Scurrilous Poet before to morrow
This time, there is no mischief in being a
Subject of ridiculous wonder.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Ask me no questions.—

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: But I could tell thee
Such a story of my Rancounters.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: But pronounce not the name of Wife.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: I'le tell thee news then; 'tis said we shall have
Wars with our Amazon neighbours.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Let it come,
I have quarrel enough to the whole Sex
For the sake of one.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: But if they have many
Such Pentheselea's amongst 'em as my Wife,
We are beaten into corners.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: I am for any thing that's desperate,
And if I do not cut as many of 'em
Off at the waste, to be reveng'd of this
Evil Genius of mine, let me dye
By their Bodkins.
sp.stage: Enter Tysamnes, Alvanes, Araxis, Draxanes, Eumenes, and others.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Call in the Embassadresses.
sp.stage: Enter Bassanes with Renone and Cydane.
sp.l: Here are our Letters to your
Queen.— We hear her Army
Is advanc'd near upon our Confines.

sp.speaker: Renon.
sp.l: But first by us denounces War;
Who scorns to gain a foot of earth, but what
Her Sword shall fairly win.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: We'll soon prepare to meet her.

sp.speaker: Cydan.
sp.l: And thus we take our leaves.

sp.speaker: Bassanes
sp.l: I hope your Queen, whose most Illustrious
Person I admire, will grant me pardon,
If in my Countries Cause I serve a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Renon.
sp.l: She honours worth in all, amongst whom Your vertues have no small effects, Acknowledg'd by the world A worthy Captain.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Your Servant Ladies.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: You shall have all Commands become your valours;
I know as men, you stand oblig'd to serve this Cause.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: To a man, Sir.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: And I (excepting one Woman)
Dare act as much against the Sex: but she
I must confess, Sir, has the better on me
In all Incounters.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Your Wife I guess;
I am glad to hear I have a Subject who
Is so kind a Husband—
No news yet of our Queen?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Not any, as the best of my Intelligence can learn.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: My soul is on the torture.

sp.speaker: Tox.
sp.l: I hope Sir, I have brought you happy tidings in this Letter.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: 'Tis Parisatis hand.

sp.speaker: Tox.
sp.l: 'Twas given me
From an unknown person, who would not stay
To satisfie my further Queries.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Let this assure you from Parisatis,

l.hi: That she is remov'd from this Life, before
It meets your hand: The means I have
Resolv'd on for my end, I will not give you the
Grief to hear, or charge you guilty of my death,

sp.l: And to confirm you, this preoedes my last being;

l.hi: I have sent you this Jewel, you must witness

sp.l: I vow'd should be kept to the death of Parisatis.
Oh Heavens! my Parisatis dead! read
Here Bassanes.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: My tears are slow, but credit me,
The death of Armies, and the groans of War
When made from gasping Friends, just drowning
Of their souls in streams of blood, ne're shook
My heart like this.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Thy griefs are truly mine.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: But hope that providence, whose paths are
Labyrinths, may yet—

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: She's dead, she's dead, too certain—

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: The King's disturb'd.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Beyond expression; Parisatis my Queen—

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: I hop'd was now return'd to your embrace.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: The other world contains her vertues, she's dead.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: My eyes can ne're want streams to pour
With yours for such a loss.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Mine are too guilty to partake
With thine; and had I more then Niobe
E're shed to drown my soul in; or turn'd
To Marble at this news like her, 'twere but
Too gentle to express my crime or grief.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: This passion's glorious.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: What death can I devise, or torments
Give my soul enough, that have at once
To answer breach of faith to thee and death of her?

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: Your stain is deep in both, though far more vile
As you are a Prince who did unworthily
Possess the love and glories
Of so excellent a Queen; that no pretence
Of Power, or Law, can expiate—
But since by Heavens decree she's thus remov'd
To Stars, for which did I but know her Urn,
I'de visit it, and pay my tears as an
Oblation to her memory—
Yet now 'tis fit you live for my sake

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Thou hast some justice to my life,
But wilt not now oblige it?

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: I do, and
Claim it as the greatest blessing of my own.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: There's nothing left me, but in thee, that can
Invite a minutes breath.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: You had my first love Sir,
So far you have an interest still.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: And for thy sake I will admit to live;
Nay more, I'le talk to thee of Love, and with
What penitence thou shalt require, acknowledge
My past vows to thee, besides the guilt of my
Ingratitude unto my Parisatis.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: Heaven must absolve your crime to both,
For this your noble sorrow.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Thy words are comforts to my soul;
But this is such an hour the Stars must mourn,
Or find new trepidations in their orbs
To fright the earth with some calamity—
Besides an Enemy does threaten now to invade
Our Kingdom— Bassanes, you shall command
As General.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: With my best duty Sir, and 'twas
Your Queens command I should continue still your
Faithful Subject.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: I have no other title here to reign but from her love,—
Admit I leave thee, fair Statyra, in some place
Of best security.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: I am oblig'd to be companion in your dangers.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: That were an endless peril, though thy vertue
Be above what fate can injure.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: My heart were else not worth the owning yours.

sp.speaker: Tox.
sp.l: A brave and gracious Lady.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: The King 'tis sure affects her.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: I feel a cloud upon my soul, I know not when
Or how 'twill vanish—
Come Statyra, my Love and thine must wait
The calmer hours of time and kinder fate.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Mandana, Daranthe, Cydane, Renone, and other Women.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: THE King may soon repent he gave our Treaty
Such neglect.

sp.speaker: Cyd.
sp.l: We doubt it not, most royal Madam—

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: And for his Queen, whose fair desertion
Has the first place in our quarrel, would she
Were now alive, that we might with our arms
Impose her on his Love.

sp.speaker: Daran.
sp.l: 'Twere to be wish'd.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: The proof we have now given by taking
This strong City of Daxata on the River
Volga, must make 'em know, their force
Must yield unto our Sexes power,
We lead— what thinks our chief
Commandress?

sp.speaker: Daran.
sp.l: I judge that victory will soon
Make offerings at your feet.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: This Pass we have
Secur'd must prove considerable, since it
Impedes all their recruits that way.

sp.speaker: Daran.
sp.l: And what's more,
Hinders provision might else arrive
Unto their Camp: nor can they forrage here
Much longer, environ'd on each side with
Mountains, where by your mighty conduct
All the passages stand seiz'd by us.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: I think
They dare not hope to force their passage.

sp.speaker: Daran.
sp.l: Our Womens hearts must fail 'em strangely then,
And make your greatness wear a blush,
To see them this day prove degenerate,
Who from your conduct glory many Victories.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Spoke like the blood of Amazons.

sp.speaker: Renon.
sp.l: Nor do we doubt the issue of this day
Will make your Prowess far more fam'd
Then brave Thalestris (stories tell) was from
Great Alexander, (the Prince of Captains)
Held in highest admiration.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: I see You are all resolv'd, as does become
This Cause I fight, by which we'll force even Nature
To confess she was a partial Mother
To our Sex, when she made man
First heir of Glory.

sp.speaker: Daran.
sp.l: Royal Madam—

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Enough, they serve
Our drudgeries, our pleasures, or embraces,
To create us Souldiers, that scorn their uses
But for our heroick ends.

sp.speaker: Daran.
sp.l: Did but the Women
Of this world besides hear this, they'd be asham'd,
To think they had not broke the yoke of men,
And such a fair and great Protectress in your self.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: An entertainment for our Greatness there,
That this haughty Prince, Tysamnes, (who dares
Make War against our Sex) may know that we
In this strong City, forc'd from his bold powers,
Keep our triumphant joys.

sp.speaker: Ren.
sp.l: Some Prisoners of War desire to present
Your Majesty with a Dance, after the
Manner of their Country.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: We admit them.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: A Moorish Lady desires admittance
To your presence.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: She has our leave.
sp.stage: Enter Parisatis disguis'd like a Moor.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Your business Lady.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: 'Tis such, most Royal Madam, must beg
A pardon for my craving this access,
Who have journy'd far, to see the glory
Of your Arms and Person, fam'd above all
The antient Amazons so much renown'd.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: The ambition of this visit we can pardon;
And glad we are our Actions have
Oblig'd the world and fame.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: But more your Sex in this
Fair Cause your arms embrace.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: This language suits
Our greatness—

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And though our swarthy clime
Cannot boast Natures Beauties in Rose
And Lilly cheeks; that gives us there as Daughters
Of the night; or that the kisses of the Sun
Were so unkindly spent, as it alone
Did darken us, and guild the world besides;
Yet we have there bright souls of honour.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: I find thou hast, above what I in this
Short view can read— thy Name?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Zeriffa, Madam—

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Thy extraction
I need not ask, I know it must be great
That represents thy self so full of noble grace
Unto our presence.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Your great esteem is
My ambition to improve, though with the
Greatest hazard of my life.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: And dost thou then love Arms?—

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: So far, most Royal Madam, as I would
Be glad to dye, though not so much as mention'd
In the lowest place, among the Annals
Of your fair Atchievments.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: I even dare
Already boast I have a Souldier in thee,
Worthy to lead with us, and these, whose veins
Are warm'd with blood of Amazons, inciting
Deeds, which but reported to the softer
Of our Sex, give tremblings to their hearts.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I should be loth to lose my share in honour,
Or miss the end I have design'd my life;
Yet must avow I never yet have fought.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Though thy Complexion above all thy Sex,
Nature has fitted most to deeds of War,
In which the scars, and wounds of arms, cannot
Dig furrows in the fair brow of Beauty,
So dear unto the vainer of thy kind.
Yet I must now require, whether no other
Motive has produc'd this inclination?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I'le soon confess I have not liv'd so much
Oblig'd by man, as that I may not justly
Be concern'd in your great cause and quarrel
To make an offering of my life.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Thou hast won my confidence.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: The command I ask from your great Majesty,
Shall be but mean, such as your prudence best
Will judge becomes a strangers trust.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: And thou shalt have it, worthy Moor.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: But crave it may be hazardous and daring:
Heaven knows how willing
I am to be rid of life.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Thou shalt have fit employment for thy valour—
And take care my valiant Women, that this
Moor, who promises such wonders of her Faith
And Vertue, does not in noble emulation
Match your Prowess.

sp.speaker: Daran.
sp.l: The Queen's soon taken with this stranger.

sp.speaker: Cydan.
sp.l: She seems to promise much.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: A suit of our best Arms and Quiver
For this Moor—
Daranthe, and you Ladies,
See her according to our warlike mode
Invested; nor do I doubt thou'lt use 'em
Nobly.
sp.stage: Enter one with Arms and Quiver.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I should be else not worthy of that Soul
I would be thought to bear.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: The Enemy prepares for
Battel, Mighty Queen.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: We will prevent 'em giving the onset first—
Mean while, let's hear a Martial Ode,
The Harmony our Womens ears delight;
While others of their Sex warble amorous
Notes to entertain their Lovers.

div.stage: The Queen Mandana leads her Amazon Women in state round the Stage, making several pauses while the Ode is Singing; at the end of which they go off.
The Amazons are suppos'd to sing the Martial Ode.

lg.l: To Arms, to Arms, the Warlike fare,
As our Heroick Charms,
With Martial Eccho's fill the Air,
Inviting unto Arms.
Our Women with their Bows and Darts,
Dare Mans rough powers assail,
And Conquer such unshaken Hearts
To give Love laws as we Prevail.
Advance, advance, lest fortunes hacte
Our Onsets should delay,
Obliging time that flies so fast,
To curb his Steeds this day;
And hand in hand with mighty fame,
That wraps in Clouds her head,
Her glorious daughters us proclaim,
And first our stately Triumphs lead.
We challenge Dian and her Host
Of Nymph - like Archers all,

l.hi: Who from their Quivers glory boast,

lg.l: Or proud Acteons fall;

l.hi: If ever their bright eyes beheld,

lg.l: A Chorus like to ours;

l.hi: Or saw themselves so far excell'd

lg.l: By Womens more Heroick powers.

div.stage: Enter Bassanes, Foscaris, Andrages, Eumenes and Draxanes.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Be couragious Gentlemen, the straight we are in,
I doubt not but my conduct with the Kings
Will find some brave expedient to relieve.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: We'l all dye at your command.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: And for the Souldiers wants, our valours soon
Shall feed, e're their pin'd bellies mutiny
For bread; my presence is requir'd to see
What order keeps our other wing.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Well Lads, we must fight it out to purpose,
I find there's no getting else a crum of sustenance.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Or be made such drudges to these Amazonia
Furies, their Camp has not the like.

sp.speaker: Drax.
sp.l: In our late skirmish methoughts they fought
Like Dragons, and handl'd their Bows with more
Dexterity then Parthians.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: There's at least
A Legion of Women, or more Evil Spirits
In any one of them.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: And should we fall
Into their hands, what might they expect
After that rate?

sp.speaker: Drax.
sp.l: As I am a Souldier,
I think a Brigade of men would scarce do
The bus'ness of one Woman of this Generation,
If they have the same vivacity for Venus,
As for Mars.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: This morning I could have been contented
To have broke my fast with one of the fair
Centinels next me; 'twas such a pretty
Hard-hearted Rogue.

sp.speaker: Drax.
sp.l: And if I starve for want
Of Bread and Women, let me perish unpity'd.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Nay, we must venture on their bodies some way
Or other; there's not a passage left us else
So wide as man enters the world.

sp.speaker: Drax.
sp.l: 'Tis said they hold
Intelligence with our Scythian
Women: and have made such furious resolves
If we fall into their hands.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: And for us Husbands—
If they Conquer—

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Eunuch'd to a Man, Gentlemen—
I look to carry my quill in my hat,

To show I am wholly castrated;
For the rest of our Troops, perhaps they'l give 'em
Leave to spin in Boots, or serve their other occasions.
sp.stage: Enter Tysamnes with Statyra, Bassanes, Alvanes, Toxaris and Araxis.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: Here comes the King; we now shall be for
Action speedily.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: His looks seem troubl'd.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Our City taken on the Volga, and
Our Provisions, the Sinews of our Armies strength
Cut off before our eyes; nay more, inclos'd
By female powers— Can you be men and live
To this contempt?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: Spare your passion Sir.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: I cannot, while I see I govern Souldiers
Scarce deserve the name of men, more fit,
By Heaven, to be converted to some other shape,
Or serve as Chamber Eunuchs to this female kind
Our Arms oppose.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: This stratagem of theirs
Was unexpected; in all my time of war,
I ne're was so surpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Think, dear Bassanes,
How we may redeem some part of this dishonour.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: I judge the way must be to attacque
Their left wing with a brisk assault.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Be it thy command. Foscaris, Andrages,
Draxanes and Eumenes, be you assisting
In this enterprise with such Troops you lead.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: To our utmost, Royal Sir.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: And hope I shall soon give your Majesty
A good account of this attempt— Madam,
I have your happy wish.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: And more, my Prayers for your safety.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: The other wing (my worthy Chiefs) I'le lead
To assist your valours.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: We all are ready with our Duties.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: And if our Swords cannot yet subdue these
Women Warriours; let them triumph,
And tell Dame Nature
'T was her fond erroneous act,
Entituled Man Superiour.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: Consider, Sir,
For my sake, as you love Statyra's being,
That have no small concern in every danger,
Threatens you.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: 'T is for thy sake I'de only live
To crown this day with victory.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: 'T were too much hazard for my Love.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Thou would'st not have me tamely gaze upon
These Foes, and see thee pine for food?
Or yield our selves to this imperious womans will,
That may, perhaps, give Laws unwelcom to
Our Loves, or take thy Beauty Captive for
Her slavish Handmaid, whom but to circle thus,
Is joy to me above the world and conquest.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: Admit I intercede for some fair peace,
She is a Woman fam'd of Royal worth,
And cannot be so cruel you express.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: I know thou would'st not save my life by
Womans mercy; besides, 'twould fright thy gentle
Person, to behold thy Sex in Armour,
And their breasts (while thine's Loves tender sphere)
Inclos'd in Ribs of Steel, with one cut off,
More furiously to wield their Martial Bows,
With other Warlike horrors to afflict thy eyes.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: I fear no danger, so I serve but yours.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Admit I leave thee in my Tent,
Attended with my best reserves of Force—
What news?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Your Army, Sir, is in outragious Mutiny
For Bread.

sp.speaker: Alvan.
sp.l: I look'd for this.

sp.speaker: Tox.
sp.l: I fear as much the Consequence.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: A sign they are sons of Cowardise
That cannot take it from their Women-foes,
Or make them knead us more.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: Your presence, Sir, may possibly allay
Their fierce disorder.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: We'le see who dares not fight,
Or starve if we command it— or else
We'le look e'm dead— your hand my dearest—
This Mutiny we'le soon compose—
sp.stage: [Exeunt. He leads Statyra to his Tent, & exit with the rest.
Enter Foscaris, Andrages, Eumenes and Draxanes, disarm'd and led Prisoners by three Amazon Ladies and other Women holding their Spears at 'em.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Nay, good Lady Errants some mercy—

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: As we are Souldiers—

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis below our Amazon honour to afford it
To such Knights of Chivalry as you are.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: As we are Gentlemen of good Nature to your Sex.

sp.speaker: Drax.
sp.l: Or as you have had kindness to man.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Or for Loves sake, of which I have store at your
Service.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.l: You are Spirits indeed of Cupid.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: I am more than an ordinary man that way,
And have Venus about me in abundance.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.l: Here comes our General.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady.
sp.l: We must not further act without her.

sp.speaker: Daran.
sp.l: You have done bravely, valiant Ladies;
But where's their General Bassanes, who
Forc'd your Squadrons? the Queen would have been glad
To have led in triumph such a famous Chief.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady.
sp.l: He fought his way with many wounds unto the
Volga; in whose rough streams we judge him drown'd.

sp.speaker: Daran.
sp.l: The Queen will give his loss some pity—
For you Gentlemen, who have not been
Injurious to our Sex in practising
Your Scythian custom; the Queen proclaims
She'l think of mercy; and for such pris'ners
Who have Wives—

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: What will be our Fate?

sp.speaker: Daran.
sp.l: It is her Royal Pleasure
They be surrender'd to their wills—
I must attend and give her notice
Of your brave success.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: 'Twere best to be afore-hand with this Act
Of Grace— I humbly lay hold on your Queens mercy.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: And I, Madam.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Drax.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: 2 Lad.
sp.l: Have none of you Wives in being, Gentlemen?
What say you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Who I, Madam? I would not be so unfortunate
For a world; and would you
But espouse us to some of your Masculine
Generation, we'd get your Queen such Heroines.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Dost hear how abominably these Creatures
Of our Loves dissemble?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: They are oblig'd, it seems, to
Change the complexion of their hearts.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Let it be for life's sake, or love's, I'le have
My due acknowledgments—

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Do not own us, dear Wives,
We beseech you.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: How, not own our just proprieties?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: As you are Women, and have mercy,
We are coming off, and on the fairest terms
Heart can wish— withdraw awhile,
And we'll be with you in a trice, and
Handle things kindly, as men and wives should do.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: You shall excuse us, we'll reprieve you Our own way now.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: And for you, Sir, whose Conversion,
I hop'd, my better stars had wrought—

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Alas! my sweetest, I love thee with a flame
As warm as thou can'st wish; but was forc'd to
Dissemble for some motives of danger,
Which I know thoul't pardon.

sp.speaker: 1 Lad.
sp.l: 'Tis fit we understand
Your business, Ladies.

sp.speaker: 2 Lad.
sp.l: You are not Spies.—

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: By your fair leaves,
We come to claim a pair of Husbands
By vertue of your Queens Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Of which, one of them had the good manners
To part with his Wife, witness my self.—

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: What will become of us?

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Or me, that have provok'd
Fate and Woman together?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: I am like to suffer under both, that must again
Endure the insupportable, and endless
Civil war of wedlock.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: O, the star of Venus has had a strange influence
In our Horoscopes; there's no resisting destiny,
And she the Ascendant.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Might I chuse, I had rather once more charge the
Amazonian Battel, and all the Viragoes
Of woman-kind together.
sp.stage: [The Ladies compass them in holding their Spears at them.]

sp.speaker: Both Lad.
sp.l: Shall we kill e'm to revenge your injuries?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: By no means, we beg their lives.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: And having thus cull'd out our Cocks,
I doubt not, but we shall manage the game
Advantagiously enough.

sp.speaker: 1 Lad.
sp.l: You have e'm at your mercy.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Thanks to your Queens.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l:
She has mine likewise in abundance Ladies—
But for you Husbands.—

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Nay, prethee we'll compose differences as you

sp.speaker: Drax.
sp.l: Now for our Capitulations.

sp.speaker: Eum.
sp.l: If we do not make fair ones for our selves
With such Victors as these,
We may curse our Nativities.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: What terms of composition, good sweet Wife?
Thou know'st I love thee above imagination.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Perhaps I may give you fair quarter.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: Let it be but in thine, and I will dye
Upon the spot, e're part with thee again;
I am thine now without a charm.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I promise nothing, though you see I have took
Some pains for your safety.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: What says my Spouse?

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: 'Tis odds she'll proceed as occasion serves.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Be not proud of thy victory, thou know'st
I have been a most submissive Husband.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: You'l soon know my conditions—

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: And if they prove but gentle,
I am conquer'd happily—

sp.speaker: 1 Lad.
sp.l: You will not leave our Camp presently?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Not till the issue of this day be past.

sp.speaker: 2 Lad.
sp.l: If you doubt obedience from your Husbands,
Command a Guard from us.

sp.speaker: Fosc.
sp.l: By no means Ladies,
We acknowledge an absolute Conquest.

sp.speaker: Melv.
sp.l: Otherwise, you know our Commission.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Your servant, fair noble Warriours.

sp.speaker: 1 Lad.
sp.l: The Queen.
sp.stage: Enter Mandana with Cydane and Renone.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: You have taken those fierce Militants
That did attempt to force their safeties
In despight of our bold powers.

sp.speaker: 2 Lad.
sp.l: We have, most Royal Madam,
And in obedience to your great commands,
Have gratify'd two Ladies of the Enemies part,
By surrendring of their Husbands to their wills.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: I am glad my victory
Does give my name a Trophy in the
Obligation of my Sex; these men we war,
Have too injurious treated— But where's
The Prince Bassanes, their General?

sp.speaker: 1 Lad.
sp.l: He forc'd his bold escape, if not drown'd
In passing of the Volga.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: We could have
Been content to have seen him made our Captive.

sp.speaker: Renon.
sp.l: And must have added
Glory to your Victory.

sp.speaker: Cyd.
sp.l: He much exprest himself your great Admirer.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Glad tidings, mighty Queen, the King and all
His power is now surrender'd to your General.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: I knew the streight we had reduc'd 'em to,
Would soon compel 'em—
And where's his fair Persian Mistress, Statyra?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: She is, besides some Pris'ners of note
Guarded by the valiant Moor.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: This Crowns our Conquest.
sp.stage: Enter Daranthe and Parisatis, with Tysamnes and Statyra, Araxis, Toxaris and Alvanes.
sp.l: Daranthe, I must praise thy valour—
And all you my Women Souldiers
For this glorious day.

sp.speaker: Daran.
sp.l: We are honour'd that our duties
Serv'd your Greatness.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: But thine, my valiant Moor, that gives
Such noble emulation in thy worthy Deeds
To all, I know not how enough to magnifie,
But soon will raise thy merit to some higher
Trust, shall speak our great esteem, both of thy
Valour and fidelity.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You oblige the humblest of your Servants.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: The King's a gracious person.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I fear too taking.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Now, Mighty Sir?

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Your pleasure, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Is it not just, that I, who am the Mighty
Warriour, in my Sexes Cause,
Should frown thee dead?

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: You cannot look me out of life, nor would
I turn my head aside, though every beam
Of yours, were Darts of Basilisks, that dare
Behold you thus—

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: You are resolute I find;
And would to Heaven your Queen were yet in being,
That she might witness my concern in her
Fair Cause; or from my power
Ask thee her Sacrifice,
Since thou hast been so much her Tyrant Lover.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: My ingratitude to her great vertue
I acknowledge; though I meet all your rage
In pouring of revenge for her sake on my head;
And since she is no more, for which, Heaven knows,
How true I grieve, I would not live, but for
This Ladies sake.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Your new made Mistress—

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: And just possessor of my heart.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: She has strange fascination in her eyes,
For which—

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: If you pronounce me guilty, speak my death;
Nay, I'le intreat it at your hand as royal mercy,
So you'l spare the King,
For whose great safety,
Had I many thousand lives, I'd humbly
Lay them, as my offering, at your feet.

sp.speaker: Daran.
sp.l: This Lady has a noble soul.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Too much the Kings I fear.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: I have cause enough to bid thee dye,
But will not cloud the glory of this day
With Womans death; and wer't not for a sacred
Resolution of my soul, perhaps would grant
Thy Loves enjoyment; but I have now decreed—

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: If death, I am ready to embrace it.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: Oh speak some milder Accent! what can
Become a Womans soul, like yours, so much
As gracious mercy?

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: My resolution's fixt irrevocable,
As when by Heaven's o're-ruling will, we guide
Our Justice: for know Tysamnes, I have vow'd
Thy life a glorious victim of my Conquest;
Nor has it been unusual in the Wars we make,
For such a day as this, to grace our Altars
With the best of Captives, of which I judge
None worthy, like thy self.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: You will not be divinely cruel?

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: I'le hear no more—
Zeriffa— take these pris'ners to thy custody;
Thy Complexion is most fit to serve this Trust;
And be sure you have a watchful eye
Upon this Lady; the rest, perhaps,
Shall find our mercy.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I joy this trust.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Grieve not, Statyra, since I dye thy Lover.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: And might I bleed upon the Altar with you,
'Twere then my Loves true Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Thus far this day propitious does appear,
But from the end great Acts their Crowns must wear.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: HOw bears Tysamnes his restraint, and our
Declar'd resolves? I know they needs
Must bow his lofty heart.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: As unconcern'd as Infants sleep,
Or as the Man you'd chuse the object of
Your mercy ought to be— nay more.—

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: What means that more?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You are a Woman.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: But a Conquerour.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Had I like power.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I'd bid him live at least.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Thou would'st not have me love him?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: No by my life—
Though 'twere a gracious Act to Heaven, if you
Vouchsafe him mercy; since he's oblig'd to fair
Statyra's Love; you else will kill two hearts at once.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Away with this fond pity;
I have fix't my Justice

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Your pleasure Madam.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Bring forth the King,
I'le make him know it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I am all confusion.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: This Moor is brave and loyal; my Mother once
Had such a Lady near her person, she
Would commend above what Faith can reach.
Zeriffa! admit none to our presence.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I shall not— but by your leave Queen
Will here observe—

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: I hear, Tysamnes,
You contemn the vow I've made,
Nor does my eye
Discern other then pleasing calms upon
The brow you seem to wear.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Such as become a King,
And every vulgar man, when made a Sacrifice
To womans passion—

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Take heed, Sir, how
You entertain a Summer in your hopes,
Or slight the Justice I decree.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: What mean you, Madam?
Alas! I look'd to meet the Miter'd Priest,
The Altar fixt, where I should bleed your Victim,
And if you superscribe it
With my crimes of Love,
Which caus'd at once my Parisatis death,
And fair Statyra's tears, I'le call it justice,
And due expiation of my sins to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: I'le soon my self convey you to the
Altar I intend—

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: What means the Queen?

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Or say I bid thee live?

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: 'Twere then a mercy greater then I crave,
Or merit.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: I'd have thee judge it more.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: 'Tis love most certain.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: What think you of this look?

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: 'Tis somewhat gentler then I did expect.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: And what of this?

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: It seems more kind then common smile.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: Is it not welcom to thy heart?

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: 'Twere too much to bestow such beams on me,
And gives me greater wonder, then should Lights Orb
Contract its glory to the Artick Pole,
To quicken there some frozen spot of earth.

sp.speaker: Mand.
sp.l: He does perceive— thy pardon now is written
In my heart— Zeriffa—
See thou respect Tysamnes
Above observance of a Pris'ner; I have
Some motives of a near concern require it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Is this your vow, oh Parisatis?
Didst thou walk as undiscern'd as Ghosts
That cloath themselves in bodies of the Air;
This must affright thee more, then timorous hearts
Scar'd with such pale horrors—
Admit, Sir, I congratulate this Grace.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: 'Twas unexpected—
And I with glader eyes could have beheld
Thee made my deaths black Hand-maid.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: You do not slight the Queen, that with her
Gracious beams of mercy quickens you to live?
Nay more, if I discern that have some trust
From her fair thoughts, is giving of her self
A conquest to your Love— methinks
This should awake your apprehension,

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: It does! but find my self
Unshaken to Statyra, and could have wish'd
Your Queens more rigid vow were unrepeal'd,
That I might bleed her Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: She is your Crime,
And therefore does deserve to be your Fate,
Or else embrace the same with her.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Though thy dark visage is most fit to be
The messenger of death and all it's horrors,
I may enquire what cause incites thee
To appear thus cruel.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: It breaks like clearest justice
From my Soul, that am oblig'd to be
Your Queens Revenger—

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: Thou art not sent from t'other world
To be my Executioner, where she's adorn'd
With Crowns and smiles of Angels, still interceding
My forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I have griev'd his Soul too much,
Pardon me, Sir, I was too bold to urge
Your penitence.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: It proves thee worthy.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: One word and I have done; were your Queen living?
Nay more, Sir, wer't soon as manifest, she
Hazarded her life, repriev'd on purpose
For your safety, would you receive her
To your embrace and love?

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: She is too dear to Heaven
To be given thence; and Stars which frown'd upon
That fatal Act, already have enroll'd her
In their first of bright Societies—
But this is all thy dream.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Believe it such—
Yet so far I dare represent her self,
As to assure you, for her sake, I'le dye
To purchase your just freedom—
Let this tear confirm you, as 'twere shed from her.

div.l: Statyra Sir.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: The carriage of this Moor
Is honours riddle to my thoughts—
Oh my Statyra! I have yet a hope of thy
Enjoyment.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: Does the Queen Incline to mercy?

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: She has receded from her vow.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: That's happy—
And more cruel in decree, seeks
To divide my soul from thine—
Thou understand'st me?

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: I do too sadly—

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: But this Moor, employ'd by Heaven
To be a Guardian of our Loves, or as
The night, or Hymen gave her this complexion
To be a sober guide unto his rights,
Devotes her self to serve our safeties.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: This means of happiness was above my hope,
While through each vein of mine, my blood had ebbings
From my heart, in apprehension of your dangers;
Nor did I view her with less horror,
Conceiving her the Queens most cruel instrument.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: I thought her so, but she has given me such
Assurance of her Faith and Love, that had
Thy beauteous figure took a veil like her,
Or were my Parisatis
Represented such, I would not have expected
A more strict concern for me.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: It seems too much
To credit from a stranger, or else 'tis but
Loves kinder Labyrinth.

sp.speaker: Tysam.
sp.l: She's here— salute her
With thy kindest beams, she does deserve
Our near regards.

sp.speaker: Stat.
sp.l: Madam, the King has given me such a character
Of your worth, as I must beg to joyn
Acknowledgments with his.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: I'le venture all that's dear to serve him,
And your vertue; but this is not a time
For Words: Things call to action—
Please you withdraw.
Draxanes come?

sp.speaker: Drax.
sp.l: I hope most happily.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: And hast thou found him?

sp.speaker: Drax.
sp.l: Yes, Madam, and have brought him.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: This place is safe from ears— wait him to me.
If fortune be not peevish now, the Scene
I have laid shall Crown my Acts.
I am wondrous glad to see thee live.

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: And I like to some man that's
Struck with Extasies of joy,
Could even resign my soul, as thus

I kiss the ground I tread, in adoration
Of your being here, when fear'd beyond a doubt
You had snatch'd your self away, to make its
Bosom in your grave more sacred.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.l: Draxanes told thee all?

sp.speaker: Bass.
sp.l: He did Madam,
As I was levying of Recruits to free the King
